comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Per various digitised newspaper hits, R.C. Hagon, tailor, appears to have been at 127 King St in 1882, at 129 King St in 1883, at 135 King St in 1885...by ca. 1886-1887 Fred Hagon appears to have taken over at 135 King St... In this pic, R.C. Hagon's sign appears to be on the building at 135 King St...which suggests a mid 1880s date...It also looks as if the Australian Mutual Fire Insurance building at the corner of Pitt and King Sts (built 1883-1884) just makes it into the frame... see comments at - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362661051/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Behind the Hagon sign there looks to be scaffolding for the dome of the Australian Joint Stock Bank (foundation stone laid June 1884) which might make this photo c.1885.  See -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362669437]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That makes sense...I wondered what was going on there.
